purpose: Test whether non-Voynich abstract systems match 40-day traditions equally well

sources_of_40_day_tradition: Widow's inheritance waiting period (16th c. British law)
critical_finding.implication: 40 days is a CULTURALLY UNIVERSAL number in medieval Europe, not specific to any domain

DECOY_B_egg_incubation.note: Lent prevented eating eggs for 40 days, but this is consumption restriction, not process duration

DECOY_C_monastic_liturgy.matching_tradition: Lent - 40 days of fasting and prayer

DECOY_D_cheese_aging.actual_aging_periods: weeks to years, 60-day FDA rule for raw milk

DECOY_E_textile_dyeing.actual_periods: days to weeks, varies by depth

summary.key_observation: Only DECOY_C (religious observance) matches 40-day tradition. Industrial/biological decoys do NOT match. This suggests 40-day is domain-specific to RELIGIOUS or RELIGIOUS-DERIVED contexts (quarantine, alchemy).
summary.counter_observation: However, alchemy itself adopted biblical symbolism. The 40-day philosophical month may simply be alchemists using the biblical 40 because it was culturally authoritative, NOT because 40 days was practically optimal.

reasons: 40 days is a GENERIC medieval number with biblical authority
Alchemists may have used 40 days BECAUSE of biblical resonance, not practical necessity
The match proves Voynich is consistent with medieval culture, not specifically with alchemy
A prayer book with 40 folios would match equally well
what_would_strengthen_the_claim: If the 40 folios had INTERNAL structure matching alchemical 40-day descriptions
If the 4-cycle structure is NOT found in religious 40-day observances
If tempo/energy profiles distinguish alchemy from other 40-day systems
